On Mon, 13 Sep 2004 15:05:46 -0400, Mark Ahlstrom <lists@...> wrote:
> > I think Ken wrote a paper on plastic synapses, is that right? - I admit
> > to not reading it yet though :(
> 
> It was actually Ken's paper that really helped me narrow down what I
> wanted to do research on.  I started with just wanting to use genetic
> algorithms to evolve the topology of neural networks rather than just
> the weights (the only application I had seen previously).  From there,
> I've gradually gotten more specific in what I've wanted to address as I
> read more papers.

Are you referring to this paper:

http://nn.cs.utexas.edu/pub-view.php?RECORD_KEY(Pubs)=PubID&PubID(Pubs)=131

The one with the food foraging domain?  As Ken points out in the
paper, an interesting result is that networks without adaptive
synapsese are able to evolve built-in adaptive behaviors so that they
can react 'on the fly' to changing conditions in the domain.

I think this is a pretty interesting avenue to pursue.  As far as
domains go, I'm hard pressed to think of domains where it *wouldn't*
be interesting to try to exploit plasticity during the lifetime of the
network.

I'd disagree with Colin that game domains would be out.  You'd
certainly want to be able to detect and rapidly adapt to various
strategies...even in very simple games such as Tic-Tac-Toe there is a
significant advantage to tailoring your strategy to your specific
opponent, rather than playing solid, generic gameplay.

So rather than trying to find a domain to which adaptive synapses are
applicable, I'd probably take the approach of choosing a domain that
particularly interests me, then just see how adaptive synapses
function in that domain.

What are you interested in?  Games?  Imaging?  Robotics?  Speech
recognition?  Data mining?
 
Derek
